Developed a basic Home Automation system using ESP32 and the MQTT protocol via the HiveMQ broker to wirelessly control two LED bulbs. The system follows a publisher-subscriber model, where control commands are sent from a client interface to the HiveMQ server, which then relays them to the ESP32 microcontroller. The ESP32 processes these messages and switches the LEDs on or off in real time. This project showcases the fundamentals of IoT, including lightweight messaging, real-time device communication, and remote automation using cloud-based MQTT brokers.Team Members : Kedar Maheshwari, Vinit Koshti, Vatsal SharmaUnder The Guidence : Palwinder SinghKarnavati University (KU)

Randomization in UVM/SV testbenches is one of the best things â€”It allows us to generate corner cases that we might never think of manually! ğŸ™‚But the approach you take with randomization makes a big difference.Iâ€™ve seen two common styles:1. Randomly generate configuration and signal values in the test.Then in the scoreboard, you need to check what was received and figure out whether itâ€™s correct or not.To do this, you often have to reverse-engineer your own test to understand what the expected behavior shouldâ€™ve been â€” not fun!2. During randomization itself, you not only generate the config and signal values, but also check what mismatch or expected behavior you are introducing.You pass this expected result to the scoreboard, and now the scoreboard just has to sample what was received and compare it â€” no extra logic or reverse thinking needed.After some hard lessons with the first approach ğŸ¥², I definitely prefer the second one now â€” makes debugging so much smoother!hashtag#uvm hashtag#systemverilog hashtag#coding hashtag#verilog hashtag#testbench hashtag#randomization hashtag#verification

Ever Wondered What Makes HashSet in Java So Powerful?ğŸ¤”Key Points about HashSet in Java:1. Unordered CollectionHashSet doesnâ€™t maintain insertion order.Why? â€”> It uses hashing to decide where each element goes. 2. Hashing LogicIt applies this formula:hash(element.hashCode()) % capacityThis determines the bucket for storage.3. No Duplicates AllowedHashSet ensures uniqueness by checking the hash and .equals() methods.4. Internal StorageInternally backed by a HashMap â€” the key is your element, and the value is a constant dummy object.5. Initial Capacity: 166. Load Factor: 0.75 (75%)When 75% full, the capacity is doubled, e.g., from 16 â†’ 32.7. RehashingAfter resizing, elements are rehashed and redistributed into new buckets. Costly operation, but improves lookup performance.8. Hash CollisionsIf two elements have the same hash, theyâ€™re stored in a linked list in the same bucket.9. Treeify (Java 8 Feature)If a single bucket has > 8 collisions, the list is converted to a balanced tree â†’ Faster lookups, even with collisions!HashSet = Fast, unique, no order, and smart handling of collisions!hashtag#Java hashtag#HashSet hashtag#CollectionsFramework hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#CodingConcepts hashtag#InterviewQuestion

I'm excited to share that my latest research paper â€” developed in collaboration with two of my professors from the masterâ€™s degree program at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Banja Luka â€” has been officially published on IEEE Xplore!Presented at the 24th International Symposium INFOTEH-JAHORINA, the paper addresses the challenge of ensuring configuration consistency in modern network devices. With the growing number of devices and the complexity of their configurations, it becomes increasingly difficult to guarantee that the active configurations align with their desired state. The research focuses on enhancing the reliability of network monitoring using the NETCONF protocol, continuously comparing configurations in XML format, and detecting errors in real-time. Our system helps identify discrepancies in device configurations and provides historical data to facilitate root-cause analysis, ultimately improving network performance and minimizing errors.ğŸ“„ Read full paper on IEEE Xplore: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/du2sg7ghğŸ“„ Also available on ResearchGate: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dqpjzNqH

Iâ€™m Iâ€™ve been diving deeper into Java performance tuning, and I came across this insightful article: â€œJava is very fast if you donâ€™t create objects.â€ It really made me rethink how I write Java code, especially in systems where low-latency and high throughput are non-negotiable.The key takeaway? Object creation isnâ€™t â€œfreeâ€ â€” even with the JVMâ€™s optimizations. Every allocation adds up, especially in performance-critical applications. The article does a great job of showing how reducing GC pressure by minimizing object creation can lead to significant performance gains.Some lessons Iâ€™m keeping in mind: â€¢	Avoid unnecessary allocations in hot paths. â€¢	Reuse objects where possible. â€¢	Data structures and memory layout matter, even in Java. â€¢	Sometimes, the â€œelegantâ€ OO design isnâ€™t the fastest â€” and thatâ€™s OK when performance is king.This doesnâ€™t mean we should avoid all objects â€” Java is, after all, an object-oriented language. But being mindful of when and how we create them can lead to JVM performance that rivals native code.Full article can be found here, with a detailed analyze: https://lnkd.in/d3KASMZxhashtag#Java hashtag#Performance hashtag#JVM hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#LowLatency

In the Java Virtual Machine (JVM), a Frame is a data structure created for each method call within a threadâ€™s Java Stack. Each thread in the JVM has its own Java Stack, which is a region of memory used to manage method execution. Frames are the building blocks of this stack, acting as individual workspaces that store all the information needed to execute a method.A Frame consists of three main components:- Local Variable Array- Operand Stack- Constant Pool Referenceğ™ğ™§ğ™–ğ™¢ğ™šğ™¨ ğ™˜ğ™–ğ™£ ğ™—ğ™š ğ™¥ğ™–ğ™§ğ™©ğ™ğ™–ğ™¡ğ™¡ğ™® ğ™§ğ™šğ™ªğ™¨ğ™šğ™™ ğ™—ğ™® ğ™©ğ™ğ™š ğ™…ğ™„ğ™ ğ˜¾ğ™¤ğ™¢ğ™¥ğ™ğ™¡ğ™šğ™§ ğ™™ğ™ªğ™§ğ™ğ™£ğ™œ ğ™©ğ™–ğ™ğ™¡-ğ™˜ğ™–ğ™¡ğ™¡ ğ™¤ğ™¥ğ™©ğ™ğ™¢ğ™ğ™¯ğ™–ğ™©ğ™ğ™¤ğ™£. In certain cases, when the JVM detects a tail-recursive method call, the JIT can overwrite the current Frame instead of pushing a new one, reducing stack growth and preventing StackOverflowError. This optimization, part of HotSpotâ€™s advanced inlining, is rarely discussed but critical for high-performance recursive code.When compute(5, 3) is called:A Frame for compute is created, with local variables a (5), b (3), and sum (8), and an Operand Stack for a + b.When multiply(8) is called, a new Frame is pushed for multiply, with its own local variable x (8) and Operand Stack for x * 2.If multiply(-8) is called instead, an IllegalArgumentException occurs. The JVM uses the Frames to build a Stack Trace, showing the call chain: multiply â†’ compute.hashtag#java hashtag#jvm

Developed a basic Home Automation system using ESP32 and the MQTT protocol via the HiveMQ broker to wirelessly control two LED bulbs. The system follows a publisher-subscriber model, where control commands are sent from a client interface to the HiveMQ server, which then relays them to the ESP32 microcontroller. The ESP32 processes these messages and switches the LEDs on or off in real time. This project showcases the fundamentals of IoT, including lightweight messaging, real-time device communication, and remote automation using cloud-based MQTT brokers.Team Members : Kedar Maheshwari, Vinit Koshti, Vatsal SharmaUnder The Guidence : Palwinder SinghKarnavati University (KU)

Randomization in UVM/SV testbenches is one of the best things â€”It allows us to generate corner cases that we might never think of manually! ğŸ™‚But the approach you take with randomization makes a big difference.Iâ€™ve seen two common styles:1. Randomly generate configuration and signal values in the test.Then in the scoreboard, you need to check what was received and figure out whether itâ€™s correct or not.To do this, you often have to reverse-engineer your own test to understand what the expected behavior shouldâ€™ve been â€” not fun!2. During randomization itself, you not only generate the config and signal values, but also check what mismatch or expected behavior you are introducing.You pass this expected result to the scoreboard, and now the scoreboard just has to sample what was received and compare it â€” no extra logic or reverse thinking needed.After some hard lessons with the first approach ğŸ¥², I definitely prefer the second one now â€” makes debugging so much smoother!hashtag#uvm hashtag#systemverilog hashtag#coding hashtag#verilog hashtag#testbench hashtag#randomization hashtag#verification

Ever Wondered What Makes HashSet in Java So Powerful?ğŸ¤”Key Points about HashSet in Java:1. Unordered CollectionHashSet doesnâ€™t maintain insertion order.Why? â€”> It uses hashing to decide where each element goes. 2. Hashing LogicIt applies this formula:hash(element.hashCode()) % capacityThis determines the bucket for storage.3. No Duplicates AllowedHashSet ensures uniqueness by checking the hash and .equals() methods.4. Internal StorageInternally backed by a HashMap â€” the key is your element, and the value is a constant dummy object.5. Initial Capacity: 166. Load Factor: 0.75 (75%)When 75% full, the capacity is doubled, e.g., from 16 â†’ 32.7. RehashingAfter resizing, elements are rehashed and redistributed into new buckets. Costly operation, but improves lookup performance.8. Hash CollisionsIf two elements have the same hash, theyâ€™re stored in a linked list in the same bucket.9. Treeify (Java 8 Feature)If a single bucket has > 8 collisions, the list is converted to a balanced tree â†’ Faster lookups, even with collisions!HashSet = Fast, unique, no order, and smart handling of collisions!hashtag#Java hashtag#HashSet hashtag#CollectionsFramework hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#CodingConcepts hashtag#InterviewQuestion

I'm excited to share that my latest research paper â€” developed in collaboration with two of my professors from the masterâ€™s degree program at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Banja Luka â€” has been officially published on IEEE Xplore!Presented at the 24th International Symposium INFOTEH-JAHORINA, the paper addresses the challenge of ensuring configuration consistency in modern network devices. With the growing number of devices and the complexity of their configurations, it becomes increasingly difficult to guarantee that the active configurations align with their desired state. The research focuses on enhancing the reliability of network monitoring using the NETCONF protocol, continuously comparing configurations in XML format, and detecting errors in real-time. Our system helps identify discrepancies in device configurations and provides historical data to facilitate root-cause analysis, ultimately improving network performance and minimizing errors.ğŸ“„ Read full paper on IEEE Xplore: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/du2sg7ghğŸ“„ Also available on ResearchGate: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dqpjzNqH

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

Iâ€™m Iâ€™ve been diving deeper into Java performance tuning, and I came across this insightful article: â€œJava is very fast if you donâ€™t create objects.â€ It really made me rethink how I write Java code, especially in systems where low-latency and high throughput are non-negotiable.The key takeaway? Object creation isnâ€™t â€œfreeâ€ â€” even with the JVMâ€™s optimizations. Every allocation adds up, especially in performance-critical applications. The article does a great job of showing how reducing GC pressure by minimizing object creation can lead to significant performance gains.Some lessons Iâ€™m keeping in mind: â€¢	Avoid unnecessary allocations in hot paths. â€¢	Reuse objects where possible. â€¢	Data structures and memory layout matter, even in Java. â€¢	Sometimes, the â€œelegantâ€ OO design isnâ€™t the fastest â€” and thatâ€™s OK when performance is king.This doesnâ€™t mean we should avoid all objects â€” Java is, after all, an object-oriented language. But being mindful of when and how we create them can lead to JVM performance that rivals native code.Full article can be found here, with a detailed analyze: https://lnkd.in/d3KASMZxhashtag#Java hashtag#Performance hashtag#JVM hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#LowLatency

In the Java Virtual Machine (JVM), a Frame is a data structure created for each method call within a threadâ€™s Java Stack. Each thread in the JVM has its own Java Stack, which is a region of memory used to manage method execution. Frames are the building blocks of this stack, acting as individual workspaces that store all the information needed to execute a method.A Frame consists of three main components:- Local Variable Array- Operand Stack- Constant Pool Referenceğ™ğ™§ğ™–ğ™¢ğ™šğ™¨ ğ™˜ğ™–ğ™£ ğ™—ğ™š ğ™¥ğ™–ğ™§ğ™©ğ™ğ™–ğ™¡ğ™¡ğ™® ğ™§ğ™šğ™ªğ™¨ğ™šğ™™ ğ™—ğ™® ğ™©ğ™ğ™š ğ™…ğ™„ğ™ ğ˜¾ğ™¤ğ™¢ğ™¥ğ™ğ™¡ğ™šğ™§ ğ™™ğ™ªğ™§ğ™ğ™£ğ™œ ğ™©ğ™–ğ™ğ™¡-ğ™˜ğ™–ğ™¡ğ™¡ ğ™¤ğ™¥ğ™©ğ™ğ™¢ğ™ğ™¯ğ™–ğ™©ğ™ğ™¤ğ™£. In certain cases, when the JVM detects a tail-recursive method call, the JIT can overwrite the current Frame instead of pushing a new one, reducing stack growth and preventing StackOverflowError. This optimization, part of HotSpotâ€™s advanced inlining, is rarely discussed but critical for high-performance recursive code.When compute(5, 3) is called:A Frame for compute is created, with local variables a (5), b (3), and sum (8), and an Operand Stack for a + b.When multiply(8) is called, a new Frame is pushed for multiply, with its own local variable x (8) and Operand Stack for x * 2.If multiply(-8) is called instead, an IllegalArgumentException occurs. The JVM uses the Frames to build a Stack Trace, showing the call chain: multiply â†’ compute.hashtag#java hashtag#jvm

Developed a basic Home Automation system using ESP32 and the MQTT protocol via the HiveMQ broker to wirelessly control two LED bulbs. The system follows a publisher-subscriber model, where control commands are sent from a client interface to the HiveMQ server, which then relays them to the ESP32 microcontroller. The ESP32 processes these messages and switches the LEDs on or off in real time. This project showcases the fundamentals of IoT, including lightweight messaging, real-time device communication, and remote automation using cloud-based MQTT brokers.Team Members : Kedar Maheshwari, Vinit Koshti, Vatsal SharmaUnder The Guidence : Palwinder SinghKarnavati University (KU)

Randomization in UVM/SV testbenches is one of the best things â€”It allows us to generate corner cases that we might never think of manually! ğŸ™‚But the approach you take with randomization makes a big difference.Iâ€™ve seen two common styles:1. Randomly generate configuration and signal values in the test.Then in the scoreboard, you need to check what was received and figure out whether itâ€™s correct or not.To do this, you often have to reverse-engineer your own test to understand what the expected behavior shouldâ€™ve been â€” not fun!2. During randomization itself, you not only generate the config and signal values, but also check what mismatch or expected behavior you are introducing.You pass this expected result to the scoreboard, and now the scoreboard just has to sample what was received and compare it â€” no extra logic or reverse thinking needed.After some hard lessons with the first approach ğŸ¥², I definitely prefer the second one now â€” makes debugging so much smoother!hashtag#uvm hashtag#systemverilog hashtag#coding hashtag#verilog hashtag#testbench hashtag#randomization hashtag#verification

Ever Wondered What Makes HashSet in Java So Powerful?ğŸ¤”Key Points about HashSet in Java:1. Unordered CollectionHashSet doesnâ€™t maintain insertion order.Why? â€”> It uses hashing to decide where each element goes. 2. Hashing LogicIt applies this formula:hash(element.hashCode()) % capacityThis determines the bucket for storage.3. No Duplicates AllowedHashSet ensures uniqueness by checking the hash and .equals() methods.4. Internal StorageInternally backed by a HashMap â€” the key is your element, and the value is a constant dummy object.5. Initial Capacity: 166. Load Factor: 0.75 (75%)When 75% full, the capacity is doubled, e.g., from 16 â†’ 32.7. RehashingAfter resizing, elements are rehashed and redistributed into new buckets. Costly operation, but improves lookup performance.8. Hash CollisionsIf two elements have the same hash, theyâ€™re stored in a linked list in the same bucket.9. Treeify (Java 8 Feature)If a single bucket has > 8 collisions, the list is converted to a balanced tree â†’ Faster lookups, even with collisions!HashSet = Fast, unique, no order, and smart handling of collisions!hashtag#Java hashtag#HashSet hashtag#CollectionsFramework hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#CodingConcepts hashtag#InterviewQuestion

I'm excited to share that my latest research paper â€” developed in collaboration with two of my professors from the masterâ€™s degree program at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Banja Luka â€” has been officially published on IEEE Xplore!Presented at the 24th International Symposium INFOTEH-JAHORINA, the paper addresses the challenge of ensuring configuration consistency in modern network devices. With the growing number of devices and the complexity of their configurations, it becomes increasingly difficult to guarantee that the active configurations align with their desired state. The research focuses on enhancing the reliability of network monitoring using the NETCONF protocol, continuously comparing configurations in XML format, and detecting errors in real-time. Our system helps identify discrepancies in device configurations and provides historical data to facilitate root-cause analysis, ultimately improving network performance and minimizing errors.ğŸ“„ Read full paper on IEEE Xplore: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/du2sg7ghğŸ“„ Also available on ResearchGate: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dqpjzNqH
